page.lettertext:
fol.71r
Belgia. 1591 stilo Ro
m
12 Fe
b
To Cap
t
Lambart
Belgia: 1591: Feb
r
S
r
, In my opinion yo
u
have taken a good course
for her
Ma
t
s
vice, to require of
S
r
John Norreis
some farder advise. For seying
e contrey doth
murmur, as yo
r
l
re
doth informe, & as I do
ceave
by theyr daily complaint
, the soundest councel that I
can give is to innovat nothing, nor to make any offer
to come from yo
r
garrison, untell yo
u
heere again
from S
r
John Norreis. For I expect ev
r
y houre
that hee or I, or both of us shalbee furder instructed
of her Ma
t
pleasure, w
ch
I will signify
yo
u
to you
w
th
all possible speed. It is not oth
r
wise to bee
thought, but that
e townes in ev
r
y place will
wrastle a litell w
th
yo
u
, and refuse to assist yo
u
for transportation of yo
r
troupes. Nevertheles to
advise yo
u
for the best I could
[.]
wishe yo
u
to
forbeare from cassing of
e companies till ye know
somewhat more of her Ma
t
pleasure. For it is
to be supposed that yo
u
shall not onely bee empeached
for coming awaie in troupes; but also
e passsage of
e
single souldiors wilbee letted for a time, w
ch
is like to
occasyon
e losse of
e Companies both to her Ma
ty
& to
e coutrey. w
ch
as you may well imagine
will turne
e common enemy to too much advantage.
Moreover for yo
r
garrison of
Diesbourgh
I see not
how yo
u
can leave yt, but ye must leave yt to
e enemy; unles
e states will take order to
send a supply wherof you see by theyr [caryes] they
are nothing carefull; This is all in effect that
I can answeare to yo
r
l
re
, w
ch
I deliver as I
take yt for the safest
ceeding, consydering ev
r
y
other is full of dout & danger
& thens &c.
Hagh. Feb
r
12. 90.
